elements.content: Fast and scalable low-temperature deposition of microscale metallic features is of utmost importance for the development of future flexible smart applications including sensors, wireless communication, and wearables. Recently, a new class of metal–organic decomposition (MOD) copper inks was developed, consisting of self-reducing copper formate containing amine complexes. From these novel inks, copper metal features with outstanding electrical conductivity (±105 S cm–1) are deposited at a temperature of 150 °C or less, which is well below the reduction temperature of orthorhombic α-copper formate (around 225 °C). However, the underlying principle of this reaction mechanism and the relationship between the corresponding temperature shift and the amine coordination are still under debate. The current study provides a full explanation for the shift in reduction temperatures via in situ characterization. The results clearly indicate that the structural resemblance and stability of the Cu­(II) starting compound and the occurring Cu­(I) intermediate during the in situ reduction are the two main variables that rationalize the temperature shift. As such, the thermal compatibility of copper MOD inks with conventional plastic substrates such as polyethylene terephthalate can be explained, based on metal–organic complex properties.

elements.content:
The Cu­(I) intermediate structure and stability during decomposition define whether copper ink is thermally compatible with printing on plastics.

Introduction

Development of flexible electronics depends on the availability of suitable metal inks, which can be deposited in an easy, scalable way. These metal inks need to comply with many criteria: they should be nontoxic, compatible with the currently used printing techniques (screen printing, inkjet printing, etc.), stable, inexpensive, and most of all curable at low temperatures to prevent degradation of flexible substrates. Motivated by substantial cost reduction, a shift in research focus from silver to copper metal inks can be easily understood from this economical, industry-driven context. Conventionally, metal inks are particle based, which means the metal is already present in its reduced state, dispersed in a solvent blend, and surrounded by capping agents, dispersants, surfactants, and so on. This proven concept allows for the deposition of both silver and copper layers, using a wide variety of sintering/curing techniques. Recently, the dawn of a second class of metal inks was witnessed, based on coordinated metal ions in solution containing ligands with a double function, stabilizing the metal ions in solution and acting as reductants during the decomposition of the precursor. These inks can be categorized in the commonly known types of metal–organic decomposition (MOD) precursors. One of the major advantages of these alternative inks is the absence of particles, greatly enhancing the ink stability and preventing operational difficulties during printing such as nozzle clogging due to coagulation in inkjet or spray-coating techniques. Very low sintering temperatures could be attained for silver inks, even at room temperature, as no high-temperature boiling or decomposing organic components are present. MOD inks are easy to synthesize and compatible with many deposition and curing methods.

elements.content: Also for copper, the MOD ink concept shows high potential for printable flexible electronics as a thermally initiated in situ reduction can be performed below 150 °C. Most of the reported copper MOD inks have a similar design: copper formate is coordinated with a variety of amine ligands yielding amine-formato-copper­(II) coordination compounds, which are soluble in polar protic organic solvents such as simple alcohols and glycol ethers. Besides the “pure” solution-based approach, copper MOD inks have been added to the mixtures of metallic copper particles to serve as a conductive “glue” between the particles after low-temperature sintering in the so-called “hybrid inks”. In many cases, alkylamines (such as hexylamine) or alkanolamines (such as 2-amino-2-methyl-1-propanol and ethanolamine) are employed as ligands. The in situ reduction mechanism from Cu­(II) to metallic copper relies on the self-reducible properties of the copper formate salt itself. The formate anions are oxidized to carbon dioxide, thereby reducing copper­(II) at temperatures exceeding 200 °C, which are considerably higher than those of the derived amine complexes. This decomposition mechanism was studied before and has been described as a complex interplay of different intermediate species, pointing to a stepwise reduction process. Although all decomposition products are gasses (CO2, H2 + CO, and H2O, from a possible side reaction), and the amine ligand will readily evaporate in the targeted temperature range (100–150 °C), only metallic copper remains on the condition that the reaction is performed in an inert atmosphere, as the resulting copper metal would oxidize in ambient conditions otherwise. The general principle is illustrated in .

elements.content: Schematic representation of the MOD ink working principle. Reducing agents such as formate anions convert into carbon dioxide upon thermal activation and only gaseous products are formed, which can be labeled as “clean oxidation” as no organic residuals are left behind.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic representation of the MOD ink working principle. Reducing agents such as formate anions convert into carbon dioxide upon thermal activation and only gaseous products are formed, which can be labeled as "clean oxidation" as no organic residuals are left behind.

elements.content: In the vast majority of research papers devoted to copper MOD inks, the resulting layer properties regarding conductivity, roughness, adhesion, or oxidation protection were emphasized. However, less attention was devoted to the fundamental question why the applied amine complexes exhibit an in situ reduction temperature which is up to 100 °C lower compared to that of the anhydrous copper formate salt, not to mention the possible formation of Cu­(I) intermediates during this process. In order to explain the beneficial temperature shift upon amine coordination, different hypotheses have been put forward. So far, Shin et al. claimed that the coordinating alkanolamines themselves have mild reducing properties assisting the conversion from divalent copper to the metallic state, whereas Farraj et al. stated that water molecules interfere in the decomposition process of the complex. Moreover, the study clearly indicated the occurrence of a Cu­(I) intermediate. Choi and Hong explained the temperature shift considering the electron-donating nature of the coordinating alkylamine, which would facilitate the release of the present carboxylate groups, and reducing properties of hexylamine. Eventually, Paquet et al. reported a correlation of hydrogen bond formation properties between the amine and formate groups affecting the in situ reduction temperature due to steric hindrance. It was argued that in complexes with “free-formate rotation” (i.e., complexes with tertiary amine ligands), the activation energy barrier for decomposition was lowered. Yet, none of these hypotheses have been validated by an in-depth direct investigation of the reduction pathway. In this paper, we will critically address these claims and provide a generalized explanation for the observed temperature shift of the in situ reduction in two commonly reported MOD ink types. A detailed structural study on both a copper–alkylamine-formato (Cu­(hexylamine)2(HCOO)2) complex and a copper–alkanolamine-formato (Cu­(ethanolamine)2(HCOO)2) complex will be presented.

elements.content: The starting compound structures were analyzed with extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements and compared to a set of crystalline reference structures analyzed with EXAFS and X-ray diffraction (XRD). Consequently, thermal decomposition mechanisms were probed with in situ X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy, EXAFS, and XRD, supported with coupled thermogravimetric (TG) experiments [TG–Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and TG–mass spectrometry (MS)]. Data treatment was facilitated using statistical methods, including principal component analysis (PCA), multivariate curve regression alternating least-squares (MCR-ALS), and linear combination analysis (LCA). Finally, decompositions of both copper–hexylamine-formato and ethanolamine-formato complexes are compared to a framework consisting of three other relevant compounds: a copper–pyridine-formato complex, Cu­(pyr)2(HCOO)2; a copper–ethylenediamine-formato complex, Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2; and the anhydrous α-copper formate salt. These three reference compounds are selected based on the remarkable spread in their in situ reduction temperatures and the possibility to obtain them as single-crystalline compounds.

elements.content: Anhydrous copper formate was synthesized by adding copper nitrate trihydrate (12.0 g, Merck, pro analysis) to a 30 mL access of formic acid (Merck, 99%) at 60 °C while stirring in an open beaker under a closed fume hood. A vigorous reaction takes place, causing the evolution of brown NO x fumes, proving the successful conversion from the nitrate to the formate species. The pale blue residue is kept in excess formic acid at a temperature of 85 °C for 1 h inside a large beaker. In these conditions, the conversion of Cu­(HCOO)2·4HCOOH to royal blue anhydrous Cu­(HCOO)2 takes place, as previously described by Martin and Waterman, for a similar synthetic route starting from copper carbonate. Stringent control of synthesis parameters is important, given the polymorphic nature of copper formate anhydrate and the related dependency of the reaction product on the experimental conditions. Subsequently, the precipitate was filtered (Pall, Supor-100, 0.1 μm) after cooling and washed with ethanol (absolute, VWR Chemicals) and hexane (VWR Chemicals). The residue was unambiguously identified as anhydrous copper formate, based on elemental CHN (Thermo electron flash EA1113 with BBOT calibration standard) and TG analysis (TGA, SDT, Q600 TA Instruments) in a nitrogen atmosphere (10 °C/min, 25–400 °C, alumina sample pan), CHN: C% 15.02, N% 0.00, H% 1.3, and TGA: Cu% 40.96.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Synthesis of Copper Complexes

Anhydrous copper formate was synthesized by adding copper nitrate trihydrate (12.0 g, Merck, pro analysis) to a 30 mL access of formic acid (Merck, 99%) at 60 °C while stirring in an open beaker under a closed fume hood. A vigorous reaction takes place, causing the evolution of brown NO x  fumes, proving the successful conversion from the nitrate to the formate species. The pale blue residue is kept in excess formic acid at a temperature of 85 °C for 1 h inside a large beaker. In these conditions, the conversion of Cu(HCOO)2⋅4HCOOH to royal blue anhydrous Cu(HCOO)2 takes place, as previously described by Martin and Waterman, for a similar synthetic route starting from copper carbonate. Stringent control of synthesis parameters is important, given the polymorphic nature of copper formate anhydrate and the related dependency of the reaction product on the experimental conditions. Subsequently, the precipitate was filtered (Pall, Supor-100, 0.1 μm) after cooling and washed with ethanol (absolute, VWR Chemicals) and hexane (VWR Chemicals). The residue was unambiguously identified as anhydrous copper formate, based on elemental CHN (Thermo electron flash EA1113 with BBOT calibration standard) and TG analysis (TGA, SDT, Q600 TA Instruments) in a nitrogen atmosphere (10 °C/min, 25-400 °C, alumina sample pan), CHN: C% 15.02, N% 0.00, H% 1.3, and TGA: Cu% 40.96.

elements.content: Copper formate pyridine (pyr, Acros Organics, 99+%), ethylenediamine (en, Alfa Aesar, 99%), ethanolamine (etam, Aldrich, >99.5%), and hexylamine (hex, Acros Organics, 99%) complexes were obtained by adding 2 equiv of amine ligands to 0.768 g of copper formate after 2 mL of ethanol was already added to facilitate the coordination reaction and mixing of the MOD ink. Ethanol was selected because of its limited ligation properties compared to the added amines, its capability to dissolve the copper–hexylamine-formate complex to form a processable MOD ink, and its low boiling point so that the synthesized complexes can be easily dried. The following complexes were found after drying and the [Cu/ligand] ratio of [1:2] could be confirmed in all cases: Cu­(pyr) 2 (HCOO) 2 , CHN: C% 40.75, N% 7.74, H%, 4.22, TGA: Cu% 16.57, blue needlelike crystals. Cu­(en) 2 (HCOO) 2 , CHN: C% 25.87, N% 19.31, H% 6.82, TGA: Cu% 24.41, purple crystals soluble in ethanol. Cu­(hex) 2 (HCOO) 2 , CHN: C% 47.32, N% 8.71, H% 9.47, TGA: Cu% 17.46, indigo amorphous precipitate soluble in ethanol. Cu­(etam) 2 (HCOO) 2 , CHN: C% 25.37, N% 10.39, H% 6.41, TGA: Cu% 23.27, indigo precipitate soluble in ethanol.

elements.content: For the characterization of the copper reduction potential in the studied coordination compounds, a thin layer of the copper complex was deposited on a Si/SiO2 native oxide substrate via drop casting and drying. This was used as the working electrode in an electrochemical cell (attached to a Cu disk), during cyclic voltammetry experiments (Autolab PGstat128N potentiostat, 50 mV/s scan rate, starting at 0.5 V vs Ag/AgCl). Tetramethyl-ammoniumbromide (0.1 M, Fluka) dissolved in ethanol was used as the supporting electrolyte, a Pt spiral wire was used as the counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl electrode was employed as a reference.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

For the characterization of the copper reduction potential in the studied coordination compounds, a thin layer of the copper complex was deposited on a Si/SiO2 native oxide substrate via drop casting and drying. This was used as the working electrode in an electrochemical cell (attached to a Cu disk), during cyclic voltammetry experiments (Autolab PGstat128N potentiostat, 50 mV/s scan rate, starting at 0.5 V vs Ag/AgCl). Tetramethyl-ammoniumbromide (0.1 M, Fluka) dissolved in ethanol was used as the supporting electrolyte, a Pt spiral wire was used as the counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl electrode was employed as a reference.

elements.content: During coupled TGA experiments, evolved gas analysis was performed via TG–MS (TA Instruments TGA Q 5000, Pfeiffer quadrupole MS, a high-T Pt sample pan) and TG–differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and FTIR analysis (Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 coupled to a Bruker Vertex 70, an alumina 70 μL cup). TG–MS measurements yield ion currents for all the selected m/z values (0.1 s per m/z time resolution, detector sensitivity of CH1000, balance gas flow 10 mL/min N2, and sample gas flow 35 mL/min N2) and time-resolved infrared spectra could be obtained via TG–FTIR (ranging between 4000 and 600 cm–1, 4 cm–1 resolution) complemented by Gram–Schmidt plots integrating all the signals in a selected wavenumber range.

TG-MS measurements yield ion currents for all the selected m/z values (0.1 s per m/z time resolution, detector sensitivity of CH1000, balance gas flow 10 mL/min N2, and sample gas flow 35 mL/min N2) and time-resolved infrared spectra could be obtained via TG-FTIR (ranging between 4000 and 600 cm-1, 4 cm-1 resolution) complemented by Gram-Schmidt plots integrating all the signals in a selected wavenumber range.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD measurement data were collected at −173 °C on a Rigaku Oxford Diffraction Supernova dual source (Cu at zero) diffractometer equipped with an Atlas charge-coupled device detector using ω scans and Cu Kα (λ = 1.54184 Å) radiation, or Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The patterns were interpreted and integrated with CrysAlisPro software. Using Olex2, the structures were solved by direct methods using the ShelXS structure solution program and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the ShelXL software package. Nonhydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined whereas the hydrogen atoms were refined in the riding mode with isotropic temperature factors fixed at 1.2 times U(eq) of the parent atoms (1.5 times for methyl and hydroxyl groups). In situ XRD measurements were performed using a Bruker D8 Discover with an experimental heating chamber, applying a 10 °C/min heating rate under a He atmosphere.

The patterns were interpreted and integrated with CrysAlisPro software. Nonhydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined whereas the hydrogen atoms were refined in the riding mode with isotropic temperature factors fixed at 1.2 times U(eq) of the parent atoms (1.5 times for methyl and hydroxyl groups). elements.content: The employed crystal structures in the present paper include CCDC 1132520 (CUFORM, copper formate) and the copper formate pyridine complex, FORPCU, which was also redetermined and stored in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) (CCDC 1856775). Moreover, a novel crystal structure could be added to the database (CCDC 1856776). The supplementary crystallographic data for this paper can be obtained free of charge via the CSD.

elements.content: X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was performed during measurement campaigns, using the DUBBLE beamline, at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF, Grenoble), and the ROCK beamline at the Source Optimisée de Lumière d’Energie Intermédiaire de LURE (SOLEIL, Saint-Aubin) synchrotron facility. BM26A at DUBBLE (Dutch-Belgian Beamline) features a bending magnet beamline, which was operated at the Cu K-edge (8979 eV) in transmission geometry ranging from 8779 eV up to 9679 eV with a 5 eV spacing just before (−20 eV) the edge, 0.3 eV in the edge region, and a constant k spacing (0.05 Å–1) from 20 eV after the Cu edge. The X-ray energy was selected using a double Si(111) crystal monochromator in a fixed exit mode. Data were collected at RT and at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C) in a closed cycle N2 cryostat to reduce damping of EXAFS oscillations related to thermal vibrations. The powder samples and references were diluted with boron nitride (BN, Sigma-Aldrich, 98%, <1 μm) and pressed in circular pellets (1.2 cm2 surface, pressure setting 40 kN/m2, for 5 min) in such a way that the total number of absorption lengths was equal to 1. All spectra were recorded using an Ar-/He (ratio 20/80)-filled ionization chamber. Subsequently, the in situ measurements were performed while heating from RT up to 400 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min in a He atmosphere in a dedicated microtome cell available at the ESRF sample environment laboratory. As metallic copper was formed after all measurements in He atmosphere, the resulting Cu spectrum was used as an internal reference for energy calibration and alignment between different samples. Beam damage was evaluated by recording spectra for 30 min on the same measurement spot and comparing the data. The data were aligned using the Athena software package, deglitched, and fitted with a k 3 weighing scheme using Viper software after applying a “through the knots” background subtraction from 3.0 up to 12.5 Å–1. The amplitude reduction factor S 0 was set to 1. The fitting models were constructed by converting reported crystallographic structures (in case of Cu­(HCOO)2, Cu­(pyr) (HCOO)2 ), remeasured (in case of Cu­(pyr)2(HCOO)2 ), or newly determined “.CIF” files (Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2) with Artemis software to cluster the structure to finite dimensions (longest path length 6 Å) and subsequently running the FEFF7 code to determine the scatting paths and their relative contribution. The E 0 value was chosen to be the first maximum of the derivative spectrum dμ­(E)/dE and similar positive E-shifts were found during all fitting procedures (7.5 ± 2.0 eV).

elements.content: The ROCK beamline at SOLEIL is especially designed for quick-EXAFS (QEXAFS) in situ measurements, using an oscillating channel cut crystal monochromator capable of covering a typical EXAFS spectrum in a sub-second time frame by selecting a certain angular amplitude Δθ around a fixed Bragg angle θB. The technical details on the working principle of the monochromator are described by Briois et al. The samples and references were measured in the transmission mode between 8650 and 10 200 eV, with an energy resolution of 0.2 eV between 8950 and 9872 eV, collecting a single scan every 0.25 s. The spectra at RT were obtained by summing 500 measurements to reduce the signal/noise ratio. Likewise, the data quality of the in situ measurements during the temperature profile could be improved by summation of 12 subsequent measurements (time resolution = 6 s, giving rise to a thermal resolution of 0.5 °C in 5 °C/min heating ramp measurements). Energy calibration and alignment were performed by simultaneously measuring a copper foil reference. The “normal graphical user interface” available at the beamline was used for normalization and energy calibration using a “pivot spectrum” for all the experiments. The samples were diluted with BN to have an edge jump of approximately 1, and the powder mixture was gently pressed in a stainless steel sample holder composed of graphite foil sealing. After the recording of RT spectra, the samples were heated up to 300 °C, with a 2 or 5 °C/min heating rate in a He atmosphere in a homemade oven described in ref .
elements.clean_text: The ROCK beamline at SOLEIL is especially designed for quick-EXAFS (QEXAFS) in situ measurements, using an oscillating channel cut crystal monochromator capable of covering a typical EXAFS spectrum in a sub-second time frame by selecting a certain angular amplitude Δθ around a fixed Bragg angle θB. The technical details on the working principle of the monochromator are described by Briois et al. The samples and references were measured in the transmission mode between 8650 and 10200 eV, with an energy resolution of 0.2 eV between 8950 and 9872 eV, collecting a single scan every 0.25 s. The spectra at RT were obtained by summing 500 measurements to reduce the signal/noise ratio. Likewise, the data quality of the in situ measurements during the temperature profile could be improved by summation of 12 subsequent measurements (time resolution = 6 s, giving rise to a thermal resolution of 0.5 °C in 5 °C/min heating ramp measurements). Energy calibration and alignment were performed by simultaneously measuring a copper foil reference. The "normal graphical user interface" available at the beamline was used for normalization and energy calibration using a "pivot spectrum" for all the experiments. The samples were diluted with BN to have an edge jump of approximately 1, and the powder mixture was gently pressed in a stainless steel sample holder composed of graphite foil sealing. After the recording of RT spectra, the samples were heated up to 300 °C, with a 2 or 5 °C/min heating rate in a He atmosphere in a homemade oven described in ref .

elements.content: On the normalized and energy-aligned XAS data matrices tracking the in situ reduction, a PCA was performed. The purpose of this algorithm is to transform a high-dimensional data set into a smaller-dimensional subspace expressing most of the variance of the original data set. The data reduction is based on the analysis of variance and is well documented and frequently applied in quick-XANES/QEXAFS studies. By orthogonal transformation, PCA converts the set of m experimental data into a set of m orthogonal eigenvectors, also called loadings, which are, by construction, linearly uncorrelated. Interpreting the structure of the loading matrix (in other words, the shape of eigenvectors as a function of energy) and considering the variance explained by each eigenvector, a decision on the number of components mandatory for explaining most of the variance contained in the data set recorded during in situ reduction is made. The eigenvalues (also called scores) associated with their respective eigenvectors account for the contribution to the total variance as the variance is the squared eigenvalue (usually visualized in scree plots, which is a representation of the eigenvalues sorted in descending order from the first one which explains the greatest variance of the loading matrix to the m ones). Moreover, the number of necessary components can be estimated by looking at the trajectory analysis of the scores for the data set ordered along the reaction coordinates axis, herein the time. This process is illustrated for the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 sample in Supporting Information S1. Herein, the “singular value decomposition” algorithm, available in MATLAB platform and specifically scripted in order to offer all the loadings, scree or trajectory plots necessary for decision, was used. Subsequently, using the PCA information about the number of relevant spectra explaining the variance of the data set, the MCR-ALS algorithm is used for extracting the absorption spectra of the chemical species involved in the reaction and their respective concentration profiles from the experimental data set. The MCR-ALS method operates an alternating minimization of the differences between the experimental data set and the reconstructed data matrix equal to the product of the concentrations matrix and of the pure spectra of the components under the action of suitable chemically or physically meaningful constraints. Herein, the constraints are the non-negativity assumed for both the spectra and concentration profiles, together with the closure of concentrations (to verify that the sum of all Cu species involved in the reaction equals to 100% closure) and with the unimodality behavior, imposing a single maximum per concentration profile. When the convergence criterion related to the standard deviance of the residuals versus the experimental data (s = 0.01) is fulfilled, two matrices can be extracted, which can be visualized as follows: one showing the pure XAS spectra of the species present during the in situ reduction and the other one is their relative contribution as a function of temperature.

Statistical Data Treatment

On the normalized and energy-aligned XAS data matrices tracking the in situ reduction, a PCA was performed. The purpose of this algorithm is to transform a high-dimensional data set into a smaller-dimensional subspace expressing most of the variance of the original data set. The data reduction is based on the analysis of variance and is well documented and frequently applied in quick-XANES/QEXAFS studies. By orthogonal transformation, PCA converts the set of m experimental data into a set of m orthogonal eigenvectors, also called loadings, which are, by construction, linearly uncorrelated. Interpreting the structure of the loading matrix (in other words, the shape of eigenvectors as a function of energy) and considering the variance explained by each eigenvector, a decision on the number of components mandatory for explaining most of the variance contained in the data set recorded during in situ reduction is made. The eigenvalues (also called scores) associated with their respective eigenvectors account for the contribution to the total variance as the variance is the squared eigenvalue (usually visualized in scree plots, which is a representation of the eigenvalues sorted in descending order from the first one which explains the greatest variance of the loading matrix to the m ones). Moreover, the number of necessary components can be estimated by looking at the trajectory analysis of the scores for the data set ordered along the reaction coordinates axis, herein the time. This process is illustrated for the Cu(hex)2(HCOO)2 sample in Supporting Information S1. Herein, the "singular value decomposition" algorithm, available in MATLAB platform and specifically scripted in order to offer all the loadings, scree or trajectory plots necessary for decision, was used. Subsequently, using the PCA information about the number of relevant spectra explaining the variance of the data set, the MCR-ALS algorithm is used for extracting the absorption spectra of the chemical species involved in the reaction and their respective concentration profiles from the experimental data set. The MCR-ALS method operates an alternating minimization of the differences between the experimental data set and the reconstructed data matrix equal to the product of the concentrations matrix and of the pure spectra of the components under the action of suitable chemically or physically meaningful constraints. Herein, the constraints are the non-negativity assumed for both the spectra and concentration profiles, together with the closure of concentrations (to verify that the sum of all Cu species involved in the reaction equals to 100% closure) and with the unimodality behavior, imposing a single maximum per concentration profile. When the convergence criterion related to the standard deviance of the residuals versus the experimental data (s = 0.01) is fulfilled, two matrices can be extracted, which can be visualized as follows: one showing the pure XAS spectra of the species present during the in situ reduction and the other one is their relative contribution as a function of temperature.

elements.content:
LCA was performed on calibrated and aligned XAS spectra in Athena without E 0 fitting. LCA includes reference spectra which were calibrated manually using a Cu foil internal standard spectrum.

Results and Discussion

The decreasing reduction temperature upon alkylamine (or alkanolamine) coordination of copper formate, as witnessed before, is confirmed and represented in . The decomposition onset of orthorhombic α-copper formate anhydrate is situated around 205 °C, coinciding with the conversion to metallic copper in an inert atmosphere. No mass loss below 200 °C was detected, confirming the anhydrous nature of the freshly synthesized copper formate.

elements.content: TGA (black curves) of copper formate and its derived hexylamine complex, together with a simultaneously recorded DSC signal (red, exo-up) and evolved carbon dioxide detection using MS (gray) for the hexylamine adduct. The images on top macroscopically demonstrate the successful reduction to metallic copper.

elements.content: Next to the neat copper formate, the thermogram of the copper–hexylamine formate complex is plotted, undergoing its in situ reduction at a significantly lower temperature (onset around 120 °C). Before that, a limited weight loss (approx. 2%) coinciding with an endothermic signal in the DSC at 79 °C takes place, related to residual ethanol evaporation. Both the copper formate and its hexylamine adduct were dried in vacuum conditions, rendering the assertion of catalyzing water molecule effect unlikely in this system. Just before the start of decomposition, a second endothermic peak can be distinguished, ascribed to the melting of the complex, coinciding with its in situ reduction. The decomposition from the Cu­(II) to the Cu(0) state seems to proceed in two distinct steps: the first is connected with an exothermic peak, whereas the second step clearly exhibits an endothermic behavior. Coupled TG–MS and TG–FTIR measurements point out that hexylamine evolves only during the last stage of the reduction mechanism (see Supporting Information S2 and S3), as the signal maxima associated with hexylamine evolution occur after those of the first CO2 evolution step (ΔT = 10 °C). Moreover, the carbon dioxide ion current exhibits a sharp peak together with a pronounced shoulder shifted to higher temperatures pointing to the existence of two separate steps ( and even more pronounced in Supporting Information S3). In other words, both the DSC and the evolved gas analysis strongly suggest a stepwise decomposition mechanism, possibly involving a Cu­(I) intermediate, as the consecutive oxidation of the two present formate anions to carbon dioxide endorses this hypothesis. A similar behavior at slightly higher temperatures can be observed for the decomposition of Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 complex, including the sequence of an exothermic and endothermic signal during decomposition (Figure S4).

elements.content: Until now, literature explanations on the reduction temperature shift have only focused on the Cu­(II) species or structure and ligand properties. However, an extensive investigation of basic Cu­(II) complex structure related properties () shows that there is no simple correlation to be found between the decomposition temperatures (differential TGA maxima) and parameters such as the (Cu–O) bond distance between the copper­(II) center and the formate anion. The same applies for the relation between the decomposition temperature and the measured cathodic reduction potential ( and Supporting Information S5). The electron-donating amine groups even lower the measured copper­(II) reduction potential, which can be intuitively interpreted as an extra obstruction for low-temperature in situ reductions.

elements.content: Overview of the investigated copper­(II) reference compounds and the two investigated MOD inks (Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 and Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2) based on single-crystal XRD measurements for the crystalline reference compounds, EXAFS structure determination (see also Supporting Information S6), TGA (Supporting Information S7), and cyclic voltammetry (Supporting Information S5). The crystal structures of the Cu­(HCOO)2 and (pyr) complex were already reported before. , The latter structure was redetermined (CCDC 1856775), whereas the (en) structure is new to CSD (CCDC 1856776).

elements.content: Although the reducing properties of alkylamines at elevated temperatures are postulated in several studies (especially in the preparation of noble metal particles), the synthesis of pure metallic copper could not be conducted with amines as the only reducing agent. Moreover, it is clearly stated that the role of alkylamines in the synthesis of copper particles is limited to the solvent or dispersing agent in the presence of stronger reducing agents such as hydrogen gas, formate, carbon monoxide, or oxalate. Claims in literature which directly correlate the in situ reduction temperature with the reducing properties of amines or the ease of CO2 evolution can therefore be considered as incomplete simplifications. If the shift of the in situ reduction temperature was solely related to the direct coordination of copper­(II) with electron-donating amine groups, it would be expected that the ethylenediamine reference compound exhibited the lowest decomposition temperature because of the fourfold occupation of coordination positions by the amine groups (see ). The experimental results clearly contradict this hypothesis. The same ethylenediamine complex illustrates the incompleteness of theories relating the reduction temperature only to the presence of N-substituents: the three primary amine-based complexes in this study vary significantly in decomposition temperature (approx. 30 °C difference between the hexylamine and ethylenediamine complex). Moreover, only one hydrogen bond between the (primary or secondary) amine and the coordinated formate molecule can be formed regardless the amine N-substitution, as the other hydrogens are so remote that the N–H···O bond lengths increase above the typically observed distances for (medium-) strong hydrogen bonds. Therefore, the effect of hydrogen bonding on free-formate rotation can only play a role in complexes with ternary amines (such as pyridine).

elements.content: It is also well-known that the coordination geometry can affect the reduction potential due to a changing structural preference between Cu­(II) and Cu­(I) species. However, the complex with the highest electrochemical cathodic reduction potential (the anhydrous copper formate) is characterized by the highest in situ reduction temperature, and no systematic order is found for the other complexes (). In addition, a correlation between the reduction temperature and the (Cu–Oformate) bond length [equatorial (eq) or axial] cannot be extracted. In concordance with the above arguments, still no simple relation between the Cu­(II) coordination structure and the decomposition temperature can be found at first sight: in Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2, Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2, and Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2, Cu­(II) is found to be in its favored, very stable tetragonally distorted octahedral environment (, Supporting Information S6). The anhydrous orthorhombic α-copper formate is characterized by a square pyramidal coordination polygon network and the Cu­(II) centers reside in trigonal bipyramidal chains in the pyridine-based complexes (, Supporting Information S6). The last two environments are considered less stable for Cu­(II), but their in situ reduction temperatures are the highest (α-Cu­(HCOO)2) and the lowest (Cu­(pyr)2(HCOO)2) of this study. Therefore, it can be deduced that the structures of the Cu­(II) species have to be seen in relation with their respective Cu­(I) intermediates to rationalize the differences in in situ reduction temperatures.

elements.content: The copper complex structure during the reduction can be directly probed using in situ XAS. The shift of the rising edge position (XANES) will supply immediate evidence on the oxidation state of copper during the thermal degradation, whereas the shape of the edge holds valuable information on the coordination symmetry. For example, the typical XANES pre-edge feature related to electric dipole-forbidden 1s → 3d transitions unambiguously points to the presence of Cu­(II) species. Moreover, the derivative XANES shape confirms the tetragonally distorted octahedral coordination geometry (D 4h , axial elongation) for the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2, Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2, and Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2 compounds, giving a further indication of the magnitude of distortion for these complexes (Supporting Information S8). Interpreting the distance between peaks B and C, the axial elongation is less pronounced for the Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 complex, compared to the hexylamine and ethylenediamine complex. In addition, the extended fine structure in the EXAFS energy range can be analyzed to uncover the first coordination shells of the occurring intermediates. Upon quick inspection of the stacked in situ XANES spectra of the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 MOD ink complex, a clear stepwise profile can immediately be recognized (). In the range between 80 and 100 °C, a distinct edge transformation occurs, taking the form of a characteristic Cu­(I) XANES spectrum with an intense pre-edge resonance in the rising edge. On increasing the temperature further, the sharp Cu­(I) pre-edge disappears again and Cu(0) is formed. PCA confirms the presence of three different species to account for 99.998% of the system’s variance, and the result after MCR-ALS iteration is displayed in as well. The three different species involved in the reduction correspond to a different Cu oxidation state, and the related concentration profiles confirm the Cu­(II) → Cu­(I) → Cu(0) stepwise reduction. As hexylamine only evolves in the last step of the decomposition mechanism, the intermediate is hypothesized to be Cu­(hex)2(HCOO). Likewise, the PCA–MCR-ALS algorithm can be applied on a Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 data set, yielding a similar reaction Cu­(II) → Cu­(I) → Cu(0) profile, albeit shifted toward higher temperatures (see Supporting Information S9).

elements.content: Overview of a reduced in situ XAS data set (showing one spectrum out of three, top), which was treated with the PCA algorithm to determine the number of components involved in the reaction (see Supporting Information S1), herein evaluated to three and the use of MCR-ALS allows to determine that the 3 present “pure” copper components (left side) and their respective concentration profiles (right side). Multiplication of both two-dimensional representations yields a close approximation of the observed three-dimensional in situ measurement. A more detailed comparison between the raw and reconstructed data can be found in Supporting Information S10.

elements.content: To gain supplementary insights into the in situ reduction mechanism, the EXAFS spectra of the isolated MCR-ALS components are fitted. The structure of the starting compound Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 was already determined before ( and Supporting Information S6), and a similar fitting procedure using a Cu­(I) model yields the structure shown in . The structural model is build based on observations from other experimental techniques (e.g., TG–MS and TG–FTIR: the presence of a single formate and two hexylamines) and the measurement of Cu­(I) reference compounds such as Cu2O, Cu­(I) acetate. The trigonal coordination for the Cu­(I) intermediate complex is fully confirmed by the XANES pre-edge intensity and shape, whereas the formation of metallic copper is confirmed by in situ high-temperature XRD (HT-XRD) (). The stable tetragonally distorted octahedral Cu­(II) species is thus converted into a trigonal Cu­(I) intermediate before reducing further to the metallic state.

elements.content: In situ reduction of Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2, consisting out of a stepwise Cu­(II) → Cu­(I) → Cu(0) transition according to the displayed concentration profile on the left hand side. The intermediate Cu­(I) and final Cu(0) structures are determined via EXAFS, XANES, and XRD analyses, giving meaning to the observations in coupled TGA-MS and TGA-FTIR analysis. The colors in the in situ XRD graph depict the logarithmic intensities (arbitrary units). More details on the Cu­(I)­(hex)2(HCOO) fit can be found in Figure S11.1.

elements.content: Once again, a similar analysis can be conducted for the Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 complex () with the aim to identify and characterize the Cu­(I) intermediate during in situ reduction. As mentioned previously, the conversion from the tetragonally distorted Cu­(II) octahedral species to the Cu­(I) intermediate requires a higher temperature (ΔT ≈ 20 °C compared to Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2). The XANES pre-edge relative intensity and shape suggest the formation of a linearly coordinated [coordination number (CN) = 2] Cu­(I) species. This can be confirmed by the EXAFS fit, which reveals a strong N–Cu­(I)–N multiple scattering contribution (focusing effect, see Table S11.2). The Cu­(I)–O distance between the copper center and the present formate anion is much longer compared to the distance in the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO) intermediate, and therefore, it cannot be considered as a part of the first coordination shell. The difference in decomposition temperature and Cu­(I) intermediate structure between both MOD inks immediately hints to a correlation, which can be explored further below. Eventually, it can be noted that the decomposition temperature range of the studied Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 complex corresponds to other, previously reported alkanolamine-based MOD inks (such as 2-amino-2-methyl-1-propanol), suggesting an analogous pathway.

elements.content: In situ reduction of Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2, consisting of a stepwise Cu­(II) → Cu­(I) → Cu(0) transition according to the displayed concentration profile on the left hand side. The intermediate Cu­(I) and final Cu(0) structures are determined via EXAFS, XANES, and XRD analyses, giving meaning to the observations in coupled TGA–MS and TGA-FTIR analyses. The colors in the in situ XRD graph depict the logarithmic intensities (arbitrary units). Note the difference between the solid and dashed line in the Cu­(I) intermediate complex, denoting the relatively large (Cu–O) distance (Supporting Information Table S11.2). Therefore, the Cu­(I) intermediate can be considered as quasi-linear in this case.
elements.clean_text: 6  In situ reduction of Cu(etam)2(HCOO)2, consisting of a stepwise Cu(II) → Cu(I) → Cu(0) transition according to the displayed concentration profile on the left hand side. The intermediate Cu(I) and final Cu(0) structures are determined via EXAFS, XANES, and XRD analyses, giving meaning to the observations in coupled TGA-MS and TGA-FTIR analyses. The colors in the in situ XRD graph depict the logarithmic intensities (arbitrary units). Note the difference between the solid and dashed line in the Cu(I) intermediate complex, denoting the relatively large (Cu-O) distance (Supporting Information Table S11.2). Therefore, the Cu(I) intermediate can be considered as quasi-linear in this case.

elements.content: In order to rationalize the temperature shift upon amine coordination, a bigger framework of similar analyses on the above-mentioned reference structures is presented in . For the most thermolabile Cu­(pyr)2(HCOO)2 complex, a four-step decomposition is found involving a Cu­(II) intermediate (detailed PCA–MCR-ALS in Supporting Information S12). The transition between these two Cu­(II) species can also be observed macroscopically due to a color change (blue to green) and in TGA measurements (Supporting Information S7 and S13), corresponding to the loss of one pyridine molecule per copper center, forming a Cu2(pyr)2(HCOO)2 dimer. It is very remarkable that the intermediate copper (II) complex and the Cu­(I) species show great structural similarities, possibly favoring a Cu­(II) → Cu­(I) reduction mechanism at low temperatures. The structural determination of both complexes via EXAFS can be seen in Supporting Information S14. Also for Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2 and the α-Cu­(HCOO)2 salt, the occurrence of a short living Cu­(I) intermediate is evidenced and supported by earlier reports on copper formate decomposition. However, in both cases, the Cu­(I) intermediate is so unstable that a 100% pure spectrum cannot be isolated by the MCR-ALS algorithm. The presence of the Cu­(I) species in the in situ reduction is therefore proven via LCA using a similar Cu­(I) spectrum as a reference (Supporting Information S15). The failure to isolate a pure Cu­(I) species by MCR-ALS is assumed to be linked to an intrinsic imperfection of the method, known as rank deficiency limitation, which can appear when two distinct chemical species evolve concomitantly, their resulting behavior in the experimental data appears as merged in a single spectral component.

elements.content: Overview of the in situ reduction mechanisms of the reference compounds, supplying the rational for the observed temperature shift. Next to the evolution of different copper oxidation states as a function of temperatures, the fitted EXAFS models are depicted. For the Cu­(I) intermediates of Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2 and α-Cu­(HCOO)2, the assumed structures are based on indirect measurements (coupled TGA) and literature.

elements.content: The higher in situ reduction temperature and the instability of the occurring Cu­(I) intermediate in the Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2 complex can be explained as follows: both ethylenediamine ligands only evolve in the last step of the reduction in the Cu­(I) → Cu(0) process (see Supporting Information S16 for TGA–MS). Given the large tetragonal distortion in the Cu­(II) complex, a quasi-square planar coordination geometry is imposed on the Cu­(I) structure, which is highly disfavored because of its closed d10 shell electron configuration. In other words, to end up as metallic copper, the Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2 complex needs to surpass an energetically unfavorable intermediate, therefore requiring a higher temperature. For the anhydrous α-copper formate (detailed MCR-ALS XANES in Supporting Information S15), the situation is even more pronounced: not only is its Cu­(I) intermediate likely to be a square planar dimeric Cu­(I) chainlike structure, as indirectly observed in literature and in concordance with the well-known structure of similar Cu­(I) carboxylates. Moreover, the strong network of carboxylate bridges in the α-Cu­(II)­(HCOO)2 structure needs to be broken apart completely, not only to end up with the metallic Cu(0) face-centered cubic structure, but also to form the unstable Cu­(I) dimers which have little in common with their parent structure. The combination of having both an unstable Cu­(I) intermediate, because of its coordination geometry, and little structural resemblance between the Cu­(II) and Cu­(I) species causes a high in situ reduction temperature.
elements.clean_text: The higher in situ reduction temperature and the instability of the occurring Cu(I) intermediate in the Cu(en)2(HCOO)2 complex can be explained as follows: both ethylenediamine ligands only evolve in the last step of the reduction in the Cu(I) → Cu(0) process (see Supporting Information S16 for TGA-MS). Given the large tetragonal distortion in the Cu(II) complex, a quasi-square planar coordination geometry is imposed on the Cu(I) structure, which is highly disfavored because of its closed d10 shell electron configuration. In other words, to end up as metallic copper, the Cu(en)2(HCOO)2 complex needs to surpass an energetically unfavorable intermediate, therefore requiring a higher temperature. For the anhydrous α-copper formate (detailed MCR-ALS XANES in Supporting Information S15), the situation is even more pronounced: not only is its Cu(I) intermediate likely to be a square planar dimeric Cu(I) chainlike structure, as indirectly observed in literature and in concordance with the well-known structure of similar Cu(I) carboxylates. Moreover, the strong network of carboxylate bridges in the α-Cu(II)(HCOO)2 structure needs to be broken apart completely, not only to end up with the metallic Cu(0) face-centered cubic structure, but also to form the unstable Cu(I) dimers which have little in common with their parent structure. The combination of having both an unstable Cu(I) intermediate, because of its coordination geometry, and little structural resemblance between the Cu(II) and Cu(I) species causes a high in situ reduction temperature.

elements.content: These newly acquired insights can directly be applied on the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 and Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 in situ reduction pathways, to understand their decomposition temperatures from a structural perspective. Both the hexylamine and ethanolamine complexes do not require extensive structural rearrangements in a cross-linked network, shifting their reduction temperature below that of neat α-Cu­(HCOO)2. In addition, both decompositions do not proceed through an unstable Cu­(I) intermediate, as (distorted) trigonal and linear coordination environments are very common for Cu­(I) compounds. Nevertheless, the MOD ink complexes do not show the same degree of Cu­(II)–Cu­(I) complex similarity compared to the Cu­(pyr)2(HCOO)2 decomposition pathway, explaining the moderate relative reduction temperatures. The slight temperature shift between Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 and the Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 can be rationalized in two possible ways: on the one hand, an extra coordination bond needs to be broken as the Cu­(etam)2(HCOO) intermediate exhibits a linear (CN = 2) first coordination shell compared to the distorted trigonal Cu­(hex)2(HCOO). On the other hand, the relative stability of a linearly compared to a trigonally coordinated Cu­(I) species may influence the required energy for reduction in both the Cu­(II) → Cu­(I) and the Cu­(I) → Cu(0) steps.
elements.clean_text: These newly acquired insights can directly be applied on the Cu(hex)2(HCOO)2 and Cu(etam)2(HCOO)2 in situ reduction pathways, to understand their decomposition temperatures from a structural perspective. Both the hexylamine and ethanolamine complexes do not require extensive structural rearrangements in a cross-linked network, shifting their reduction temperature below that of neat α-Cu(HCOO)2. In addition, both decompositions do not proceed through an unstable Cu(I) intermediate, as (distorted) trigonal and linear coordination environments are very common for Cu(I) compounds. Nevertheless, the MOD ink complexes do not show the same degree of Cu(II)-Cu(I) complex similarity compared to the Cu(pyr)2(HCOO)2 decomposition pathway, explaining the moderate relative reduction temperatures. The slight temperature shift between Cu(hex)2(HCOO)2 and the Cu(etam)2(HCOO)2 can be rationalized in two possible ways: on the one hand, an extra coordination bond needs to be broken as the Cu(etam)2(HCOO) intermediate exhibits a linear (CN = 2) first coordination shell compared to the distorted trigonal Cu(hex)2(HCOO). On the other hand, the relative stability of a linearly compared to a trigonally coordinated Cu(I) species may influence the required energy for reduction in both the Cu(II) → Cu(I) and the Cu(I) → Cu(0) steps.

elements.content: In general, this study shows the great importance of a detailed structural study to account for the ability of MOD ink complexes to be reduced at low temperatures. The occurrence of the Cu­(I) intermediate imposes an important design rule for copper MOD inks: its stability and structural resemblance to the Cu­(II) precursor is crucial for attaining a low-temperature decomposition. It enables us to understand why decomposition of the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 MOD ink falls in a suitable temperature range to deposit metallic copper on sensitive substrates such as polyethylene terephthalate (see Supporting Information S17) or paper, whereas the Cu­(en)2(HCOO)2 complex would not be a good candidate. The occurrence of a Cu­(I) intermediate and its essential influence on the temperature shift of the in situ reduction mechanism can be even strengthened further by the observation that the reduction temperature of nickel formate to metallic nickel cannot be shifted to the same extent via amine coordination (Supporting Information S18) because of the lack of Ni­(I) chemistry. Once more, this illustrates that the formation of intermediate Cu­(I) complexes needs to be facilitated as much as possible in order to reach an as low as possible processing temperature. In order to achieve this facilitation, the Cu­(I) complexes formed during the transformation of the Cu­(II) precursor complex into the final Cu metal need to show as high as possible structural resemblance to the Cu­(II) parent and need to have a favorable stability, as determined by their coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text: In general, this study shows the great importance of a detailed structural study to account for the ability of MOD ink complexes to be reduced at low temperatures. The occurrence of the Cu(I) intermediate imposes an important design rule for copper MOD inks: its stability and structural resemblance to the Cu(II) precursor is crucial for attaining a low-temperature decomposition. It enables us to understand why decomposition of the Cu(hex)2(HCOO)2 MOD ink falls in a suitable temperature range to deposit metallic copper on sensitive substrates such as polyethylene terephthalate (see Supporting Information S17) or paper, whereas the Cu(en)2(HCOO)2 complex would not be a good candidate. The occurrence of a Cu(I) intermediate and its essential influence on the temperature shift of the in situ reduction mechanism can be even strengthened further by the observation that the reduction temperature of nickel formate to metallic nickel cannot be shifted to the same extent via amine coordination (Supporting Information S18) because of the lack of Ni(I) chemistry. Once more, this illustrates that the formation of intermediate Cu(I) complexes needs to be facilitated as much as possible in order to reach an as low as possible processing temperature. In order to achieve this facilitation, the Cu(I) complexes formed during the transformation of the Cu(II) precursor complex into the final Cu metal need to show as high as possible structural resemblance to the Cu(II) parent and need to have a favorable stability, as determined by their coordination geometry.

elements.content: In summary, it was shown that all the in situ reduction mechanisms of copper formate related coordination compounds proceed via a transient Cu­(I) intermediate. The presence of this intermediate has been directly detected via PCA–MCR-ALS analysis of in situ XAS measurements or has been verified with great certainty based on LCA. In addition, via an in-depth follow-up of the complex structures of the Cu­(hex)2(HCOO)2 and Cu­(etam)2(HCOO)2 MOD inks and a selection of reference compounds, it was inferred that the reduction temperature is related to two important factors. On the one hand, the relative stability of the Cu­(I) intermediate itself and, on the other hand, the structural similarities between the respective Cu­(II) and Cu­(I) species along the thermal decomposition route. The revelation of these new explanatory variables shed new light on the design of copper MOD inks for the development of printable flexible electronics.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, it was shown that all the in situ reduction mechanisms of copper formate related coordination compounds proceed via a transient Cu(I) intermediate. The presence of this intermediate has been directly detected via PCA-MCR-ALS analysis of in situ XAS measurements or has been verified with great certainty based on LCA. In addition, via an in-depth follow-up of the complex structures of the Cu(hex)2(HCOO)2 and Cu(etam)2(HCOO)2 MOD inks and a selection of reference compounds, it was inferred that the reduction temperature is related to two important factors. On the one hand, the relative stability of the Cu(I) intermediate itself and, on the other hand, the structural similarities between the respective Cu(II) and Cu(I) species along the thermal decomposition route. The revelation of these new explanatory variables shed new light on the design of copper MOD inks for the development of printable flexible electronics.

cln_elements.content: Schematic representation of the MOD ink working principle. Reducing agents such as formate anions convert into carbon dioxide upon thermal activation and only gaseous products are formed, which can be labeled as “clean oxidation” as no organic residuals are left behind.
